title: James Turrell
sum: Excited to see James Turrell: 67 68 69 exhibition in Pace Galery tomorrow, I started a quest to have a peak at the beloved (even by Drake!) lighting artist's work and interviews. I am fascinated by the Roden Crater, which was started in the 1960s and continue to evolve over the years as the artist's grand piece of work. 67 68 69 is focused exclusively on Turrell‚Äôs first light works and schematic drawings from the late 1960s, presumably 1967‚Äî1969 as the title suggests.

links.title: James Turrell
links.description: ‚ÄúMy work is more about your seeing than it is about my seeing, although it is a product of my seeing. I‚Äôm also interested in the sense of presence of space; that is space where you feel a presence, almost an entity ‚Äî that physical feeling and power that space can give.‚Äù

links.title: About James Turrell
links.description: His fascination with the phenomena of light is ultimately connected to a very personal, inward search for mankind‚Äôs place in the universe. Influenced by his Quaker faith, which he characterizes as having a ‚Äústraightforward, strict presentation of the sublime,‚Äù Turrell‚Äôs art prompts greater self-awareness through a similar discipline of silent contemplation, patience, and meditation.

links.title: Did Drake‚Äôs New Video Get Its Bling from James Turrell‚Äôs Light Installations?
links.description: The internet almost exploded last night when Drake dropped the music video for his track, ‚ÄúHotline Bling.‚Äù But while the Steve Jobs-esque turtleneck he wears while rapping and his very intriguing dance moves dominated the discourse online, what has received far less attention are the video‚Äôs backdrops of glowing neon gradients, which closely resemble James Turrell‚Äòs light installations. ‚Ä¶ Turrell has issued the following statement in response: ‚ÄúWhile I am truly flattered to learn that Drake f*cks with me, I nevertheless wish to make clear that neither I nor any of my woes was involved in any way in the making of the Hotline Bling video.‚Äù

links.title: James Turrell at Guggenheim Museum
links.description: This exhibition, Turrell‚Äôs first solopresentation in a New York museum since 1980, considers the dominant themes explored by the artist for nearly fifty years, focusing on his explorations of perception, light, color, and space and the critical role of site specificity in his practice. It features a selection of early works, drawn from the museum‚Äôs Panza Collection as well as loans, that introduces visitors to the artist‚Äôs first statements in light. However, the show‚Äôs centerpiece is Aten Reign (2013), a major new project created specifically for the Guggenheim that reimagines the rotunda of Frank Lloyd Wright‚Äôs iconic building as one of Turrell‚Äôs luminous and immersive

links.title: Interview Magazine: James Turrell
links.description: JAMES TURRELL: It‚Äôs about perception. For me, it‚Äôs using light as a material to influence or affect the medium of perception. I feel that I want to use light as this wonderful and magic elixir that we drink as Vitamin D through the skin‚Äîand I mean, we are literally light-eaters‚Äîto then affect the way that we see. We live within this reality we create, and we‚Äôre quite unaware of how we create the reality. So the work is often a general koan into how we go about forming this world in which we live, in particular with seeing.

links.title: Roden Crater
links.description: Roden Crater, located in the Painted Desert region of Northern Arizona, is an unprecedented large-scale artwork created within a volcanic cinder cone by light and space artist James Turrell. Representing the culmination of the artist‚Äôs lifelong research in the field of human visual and psychological perception, Roden Crater is a controlled environment for the experiencing and contemplation of light. It takes its place within the tradition of American landscape art that began in the 1960s, requiring a journey to visit the work in the remote desert with truly dark night skies. While minimally invasive to the external natural landscape, internally the red and black cinder has been transformed into special engineered spaces where the cycles of geologic and celestial time can be directly experienced. It will constitute a truly culminating phenomenon in world art.

links.title: James Turrell: "Roden Crater"
links.description: ART21: Where are we, right now? Could you describe your first sighting of Roden Crater‚Äîhow you knew this would be the one you wanted to use? What started you on a quest for this place? Why do you want to work with light? Can works of art impart a sense of spirituality?

links.title: SEGMENT: James Turrell in "Spirituality"
links.description: The final segment in "Spirituality" features James Turrell, known for his use of light as the primary material in his work. From his Quaker Meeting House to his "Roden Crater" project, the artist has devoted his life to capturing the ethereal properties of light and its powers to evoke transcendence and the sublime. Pursuing his vision at a great sacrifice, Turrell wryly comments "People often ask me how much this crater costs. It cost me two marriages and a relationship." This segment focuses on two new works in Houston, Texas‚Äîan underground tunnel of light and a skyspace in the ceiling of a Friends meetinghouse‚Äîin addition to Turrell's life's work in Arizona's remote Painted Desert‚Äîthe "Roden Crater."

links.title: New Light Fixture for a Famous Rotunda - James Turrell Plays With Color at the Guggenheim
links.description: James Turrell‚Äôs exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum will probably be the bliss-out environmental art hit of the summer. This is primarily because of the ravishing ‚ÄúAten Reign,‚Äù an immense, elliptical, nearly hallucinatory play of light and color that makes brilliant use of the museum‚Äôs famed rotunda and ocular skylight. The latest site-specific effort from Mr. Turrell, ‚ÄúAten Reign‚Äù is close to oxymoronic: a meditative spectacle.

links.title: Conservative Quakers (Conservative Friends)
links.description: Conservative Friends refers to members of a certain branch of the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers). In the United States of America, Conservative Friends belong to three Yearly Meetings, Ohio, North Carolina, and Iowa. English Friends affiliated with the Conservative branch tend to use the term Primitive, or (less frequently) Plain. There is no single unifying association of Conservative Friends, unlike three of the other branches of Quakerism in America, represented by Friends United Meeting, Evangelical Friends International, and Friends General Conference.

title: Beauty ‚Äî Cooper Hewitt Design Triennial Part I
sum: Exhibitions are not easy subjects. I often go to them and come back completely puzzled. I would give comments based on almost nothing concrete, and often feel embarrassed soon after about then entitled opinion. What is worse is that I often feel the urge to get opinions/knowledge out of my brain instead of absorbing new ideas into my brain - the natural instinct to impress people, and study is almost always contra-intuitsive. Here is the first installment of a series of research into 250 pieces of work from 63 designers around the globe on display at Beauty ‚Äî Cooper Hewitt Design Triennial 2016.

links.title: Cooper Hewitt Triennial Offers a Bold Look at ‚ÄòBeauty‚Äô
links.description: This year‚Äôs version of the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum‚Äôs always interesting Design Triennial boldly ventures to tackle one of the most controversial topics in today‚Äôs visual culture. With more than 250 works by 63 designers from around the world in a jam-packed, two-floor show, ‚ÄúBeauty‚Äù is a mixed, visually cacophonous bag in terms of quality. But whether or not everything in it qualifies as incontrovertibly beautiful, it‚Äôs an exciting opportunity to meditate on the perennially confounding questions: What is beauty? And what is it good for?

links.title: The Haas Brothers
links.description: The Haas Brothers, twins Nikolai and Simon (b. 1984), had a creative upbringing in Austin, Texas where their opera singer mother, actor brother and sculptor father taught them to play music, write, sing and paint. Starting in their early teens, they studied stone carving under their father, mastering the craft before leaving home. The twins parted ways in 2003 to pursue their artistic goals individually. Simon studied painting at RISD while Nikolai toured as a musician. In 2007, the two reconvened in Los Angeles to tour with the band RRIICCEE, then founded The Haas Brothers there in 2010 when L.A. architects Johnston Marklee offered a chance to collaborate on a friend's project. Early on, the brothers received accolades for their exceptional craftsmanship and expansive studio practice. The years since have seen them evolve from fabricators and collaborators to nimble cross-pollinators in creative disciplines including fashion, film, music, art and design.

links.title: Elastic
links.description: Elastic is a full-service design studio launched in Santa Monica in 2008 by the founders of editorial company Rock Paper Scissors and visual effects boutique a52. Elastic is home to a diverse collection of artists that tell stories in a variety of mediums including motion graphics, animation, live action and CG.

links.title: Neri Oxman
links.description: Architect and designer Neri Oxman is the Sony Corporation Career Development Professor and Associate Professor of Media Arts and Sciences at the MIT Media Lab, where she founded and directs the Mediated Matter design research group. Her group conducts research at the intersection of computational design, digital fabrication, materials science and synthetic biology and applies that knowledge to design across scales from the micro scale to the building scale. Her goal is to enhance the relationship between the built and the natural environments by employing design principles inspired or engineered by Nature and implementing them in the invention of novel digital design technologies. Areas of application include product and architectural design, as well as digital fabrication and construction.

links.title: Interview With Artist-duo the Haas Brothers
links.description: ‚Ä¶ in the years since, the brothers have continued to grow their design studio and spend their time prototyping forms and experimenting with materials, surface textures and processes. they have gradually evolved into a multifaceted operation and has garnered international accolades for set design and props for print and video, one of a kind fashion works and their highly original furniture and object designs. designboom spoke to niki and simon ahead of their upcoming show at R and company in november.

links.title: Two of a Kind
links.description: Twins Nikolai and Simon Haas are using their combined talents‚Äîa wild eye for artistry, traditional carpentry skills and a deep Hollywood Rolodex‚Äîto become some of the most innovative furniture makers around

links.title: Masters of Sex
links.description: One for ‚ÄúMasters of Sex‚Äù is a comical sequence of sexually suggestive but not explicit images, like an erupting champagne bottle.

links.title: True Detective
links.description: Those for both seasons of ‚ÄúTrue Detectives‚Äù are surrealistic montages of worried faces, bleak landscapes and atmospheric commotion, summing up with terrific intensity the show‚Äôs noirish melodrama.

links.title: Otaared - Mercury‚Äôs Wonderer
links.description: Named after the Roman deity Mercury (Arabic: Otaared ÿπÿ∑ÿßÿ±ÿØ), the messenger to the gods, the planet Mercury lacks any atmosphere, making it susceptible to impacts over its entire surface. The expression mercurial is typically used to refer to something or someone erratic, volatile or unstable, derived from Mercury's swift flights from place to place. Otaared is designed as antler-like extensions of the scapulae to protect the head. The 3D printed structure is computationally grown from the scapulae and the sternum outward generating a branched winged exoskeleton. The printed shell is designed to contain calcifying bacteria grown within a wearable Caduceus. The ultimate goal is to grow true bone structures acting as protective exoskeleton.

links.title: MIT Media Lab‚Äôs Mediated Matter Group
links.description: The Mediated Matter group is dedicated to the development and application of novel processes that enable and support the design of physical matter, and its adaptability to environmental conditions in the creation of form. Our research integrates computational form-finding strategies with biologically inspired fabrication. This enables mediating synergies between objects and environment; between humans and objects; and between humans and environment. Our goal is to enhance the relation between natural and man-made environments by achieving high degrees of design customization and versatility, environmental performance integration, and material efficiency. We seek to establish new forms of design and novel processes of material practice at the intersection of computer science, material engineering, design and ecology, with broad applications across multiple scales.

title: Jan Tschichold ‚Äì Typographic Genius
sum: Jan(pronounced Yahn) Tschichold(pronounced Chih-kold) was someone who would change his name because he changed his opinion on type design or he was inspired by a new design style.  He is a typographic genius, "a titan of typography" (The Guardian), yet he is "the most severe critic of the young self".  His legacy is still influencing the web typography era that he was not able to be part of. Technology is the surface, the medium; whereas the thinking, the philosophy is the root.

links.title: Jan Tschichold ‚Äì Typographic Genius
links.description: Jan Tschichold left an impression upon the world of graphic design and typography that few could compete against. From strongly advocating the beauty of sans serif fonts and clean, organised design 20 years before it took off, to strengthening the design of Penguin books to turn them into the something special that they are. Jan Tschichold spent a life learning and exploring and left us with much to do the same.

links.quote: Regardless of Tzschichhold‚Äôs skill, there was something about all these colourful posters and books at the Bauhaus that must‚Äôve sent shivers down his spine. Consequently, Johannes was so enamoured by this material that he wrote to designers all across Europe asking them for copies of their work. Later, he would rename himself ‚ÄúIwan‚Äù (pronounced Ivan) and simplify his surname to ‚ÄúTschichold‚Äù, in honour of this underground style that had quickly become his inspiration.

links.title: Pierre Simon Fournier
links.description: Pierre-Simon Fournier (15 September 1712 ‚Äì 8 October 1768) was a French mid-18th century punch-cutter, typefounder and typographic theoretician. He was both a collector and originator of types. Fournier's contributions to printing were his creation of initials and ornaments, his design of letters, and his standardization of type sizes. He worked in the rococo form, and designed typefaces including Fournier and Narcissus. He was known for incorporating ‚Äòdecorative typographic ornaments‚Äô into his typefaces. Fournier's main accomplishment is that he ‚Äòcreated a standardized measuring system that would revolutionize the typography industry forever‚Äô.

links.title: Sabon
links.description: Sabon is an old-style serif typeface designed by the German-born typographer and designer Jan Tschichold (1902‚Äì1974) in the period 1964‚Äì1967. It was released jointly by the Linotype, Monotype, and Stempel type foundries in 1967. The design of the roman is based on types by Claude Garamond (c.1480‚Äì1561), particularly a specimen printed by the Frankfurt printer Konrad Berner. Berner had married the widow of a fellow printer Jacques Sabon, the source of the face's name, who had bought some of Garamond's type after his death.

links.title: The New Typography (Weimar and Now: German Cultural Criticism)
links.description: Since its initial publication in Berlin in 1928, Jan Tschichold's The New Typography has been recognized as the definitive treatise on book and graphic design in the machine age. First published in English in 1995, with an excellent introduction by Robin Kinross, this new edition includes a foreword by Rich Hendel, who considers current thinking about Tschichold's life and work.

links.title: Jan Tschichold, Master Typographer: His Life, Work and Legacy
links.description: Few have left a deeper impression on the world of typography than Jan Tschichold (1902-1974), one of the most outstanding and influential designers of the twentieth century. Not only was he a master in his field, but he also lectured on the subject, wrote a number of highly influential books, and designed many classic typefaces, including the best-selling Sabon.

links.title: In Honor of the 100th Birthday of Jan Tschichold
links.description: Jan Tschichold is one of the most outstanding and influential typographers of the 20th century. He was a master in his field, worked as a teacher, wrote a number of books, designed typefaces, and worked his entire life as designer and writer. The significance of his influence on the print industry and designers in Europe and the USA is uncontested and his famous typeface Sabon is still a bestseller. In honor of his 100th birthday, Linotype is dedicating this review of his life and work.

links.title: Jan Tschichold: a titan of typography
links.description: The man who perfected Penguin's classic paperback deserves to be remembered as one of the great designers of the 20th century

links.title: Tschichold, Nazis and Allen Lane: the Modernist Politics of Type
links.description: Reader, if you feel that perhaps typography is trivial in the history of culture, look no further than this minor incident in Nazi lore as refutation. The Nazis were willing to imprison people not because of their beliefs in religion or politics per se, but because of their beliefs about typography.

title: Algorithms for Generative Art
sum: Today I collect links about algorithms that can be used to make generative art. I focused on two main topics: Fractal and Noise (Perlin Noise and Simplex Noise). I wished to find a third topic that is equally interesting but failed. Both of these two topics are so unique and rare, they involve beautiful math, which is always my favorite, and at the same time, the application of the math is so natively graphical, therefore naturally good for making generative art. As a result of doing this research, I bought one of the books I posted here ‚Äî this project is getting expensive!

links.title: An Introduction to Fractals
links.description: What is a fractal? B. Mandelbrot: A rough or fragmented geometric shape that can be subdivided in parts, each of which is (at least approximately) a reduced/size copy of the whole. Mathematical: A set of points whose fractal dimension exceeds its topological dimension.

links.title: What are Fractals and why should I care?
links.description: This blog post shall give a quick overview of how to make fractal shapes and show how these shapes can resemble nature. It shall then go on to talk about dimensionality, which is a cool way to measure fractals. It ends by discussing how fractal geometry is also beneficial because randomness can be introduced into the structure of a fractal shape. The post requires almost no maths and includes lot of pretty pictures

links.title: The Fractal Geometry of Nature
links.description: Clouds are not spheres, mountains are not cones, and lightening does not travel in a straight line. The complexity of nature's shapes differs in kind, not merely degree, from that of the shapes of ordinary geometry, the geometry of fractal shapes.

links.title: Introducing Fractals: A Graphic Guide
links.description: Fractal Geometry is the geometry of the natural world - animal, vegetable and mineral. It's about the broken, wrinkled, wiggly world - the uneven shapes of nature, unlike the idealized forms of Euclidean geometry. We see fractals everywhere; indeed we are fractal! Fractal Geometry is an extension of classical geometry. Using computers, it can make precise models of physical structures - from ferns to galaxies. Fractal geometry is a new language. Once you speak it, you can describe the shape of cloud as precisely as an architect can describe a house.

links.title: Infinite Arboretum
links.description: Click to generate a new random tree. Move the mouse left and right to push the tree. Press ‚ÄúA‚Äù to enable auto-play. Press ‚ÄúP‚Äù to enable background painting. Press ‚ÄúW‚Äù to toggle wind. Press ‚ÄúR‚Äù to regrow the current type of tree. Press ‚ÄúB‚Äù to randomize the background color. Press ‚ÄúC‚Äù to randomize the tree colors. This sketch was made with Processing 2 in Javascript mode.

links.title: Simplex noise demystified
links.description: In 2001, Ken Perlin presented ‚Äúsimplex noise‚Äù, a replacement for his classic noise algorithm. Classic ‚ÄúPerlin noise‚Äù won him an academy award and has become an ubiquitous procedural primitive for computer graphics over the years, but in hindsight it has quite a few limitations. Ken Perlin himself designed simplex noise specifically to overcome those limitations, and he spent a lot of good thinking on it.

links.title: Perlin Noise
links.description: Many people have used random number generators in their programs to create unpredictability, make the motion and behavior of objects appear more natural, or generate textures. Random number generators certainly have their uses, but at times their output can be too harsh to appear natural. This article will present a function which has a very wide range of uses, more than I can think of, but basically anywhere where you need something to look natural in origin. What's more it's output can easily be tailored to suit your needs.

links.title: simplex-noise.js
links.description: simplex-noise.js is a fast simplex noise implementation in Javascript. It works in the browser and on nodejs.

links.title: noise.js
links.description: This is a simple library for 2d & 3d perlin noise and simplex noise in javascript. Noise is pretty. The library is pretty fast (10M queries / sec). But its still way slower than using a shader. For example, if you try and update an entire screen's worth of pixels, it'll be slow. The code is based on Stefan Gustavson's implementation.

links.title: Natural Simulations: Noise
links.description: This "Natural Simulations" course is a derivative of "The Nature of Code" by Daniel Shiffman

title: Shapes
sum: These links are mostly about using CSS shape to create more dynamic web layout. The rest are links to cool projects and opinion essays around the topic ‚Äúshape‚Äù.

links.title: Why you should be excited about CSS shapes
links.description: CSS shapes is being developed by the Adobe Web Platform team and they have blogged about how this spec has been developing since 2012. Check out the cool demo the team built, based on Alice in Wonderland, to showcase CSS shapes‚Äô capabilities. Point is, with CSS shapes, it‚Äôs totally possible to have text wrap around Beyonc√©‚Äôs elbow.

links.title: Own a Shape
links.description: Visual identity takes many forms, from the most superficial of trademarks to the most integrated of design signatures. Shapes are part of its language. At their most basic, shapes are universal, untetherable to any name, product, or brand. But in context, in their intersections and in the synthesis of forms, they are powerful.

links.title: The Shape Christmas
links.description: Started in 2011, here at Shape we created a collaboration project that connected students, graduates and industry professionals together. We created a digital platform to enable creatives to create artwork free for download to end users on iPhone & iPad. The process is simple. A digital calendar that counts down to christmas and reveals a bespoke illustration each day themed around 4 different Shapes (Square, Triangle, Circle and Hexagon) & Christmas! 25 creatives are chosen to feature their artwork from all over the world.

links.title: Maskew
links.description: A JS library for skewing the shapes of elements.

links.title: Shape Shifter
links.description: An experiment by Kenneth Cachia. Font Awesome is being used to render all #icons.

links.title: Shape Blobbing in CSS
links.description: We just covered shape morphing in SVG, where shapes change from one to another. Let's look at shapes that blob into each other! You know, that gooey squishy blobby effect like droplets of mercury on a surface.

links.title: The Shape of Materials to Come
links.description: We wanted to start with something simple, and yet show the behavior we wanted to have. So we started with different shapes and determined some rules. Bubble Gum material ‚Äì outwards animations. Marshmallow material ‚Äì imploding animations and softer reaction. Jawbreaker material ‚Äì subtle bouncy animations. Jelly material ‚Äì subtle bouncy animations.

links.title: Philographics
links.description: Philographics is a series of posters that explains big ideas in simple shapes. They are the result of combining the world of philosophy with graphic design. You can get the entire set of 95 designs as a book or a selection of them as posters and postcards.

links.title: Getting Started with CSS Shapes
links.description: For a long time, web designers have been forced to create within the constraints of the rectangle. Most content on the web is still trapped in simple boxes because most creative ventures into non-rectangular layout end in frustration. That is about to change with the introduction of CSS Shapes, available starting with Chrome 37.

links.title: Animating CSS Shapes with CSS Animations and Transitions
links.description: Today we're going to be talking about animating CSS shapes with CSS animations. We'll be creating very basic "shape-shifting" layouts of sort. There are also many considerations to take when animating CSS shapes, so we'll go over all points in this article.

links.title: Using CSS Shapes to Enhance Visual Storytelling
links.description: All that is about to change with the implementation of CSS Shapes, a new standard which allows web designers and developers to wrap content inside or around custom shapes. Shapes are defined in simple, practical, and reusable ways; most importantly, unlike most CSS hacks that just simulate shapes, they can affect the entire layout of a web page.

links.title: CSS Shapes Editor for Chrome
links.description: CSS Shapes Editor for Chrome is a Developer Tools extension which provides an interactive editor for shape property values like circle(), ellipse() and polygon().

links.title: Using CSS Regions With CSS Shapes For A Better Reading Experience
links.description: Using CSS shapes we can flow our content in non-rectangular areas. And sometimes we want to be able to flow our content into multiple custom-shaped areas inside an element. If you've read my previous article, you already know that this can be done with CSS Shapes, by using an image with alpha transparency with multiple shapes defined in it, and letting the browser extract the content's float areas from it. As appealing as this may sound and as creative as we can get with our shapes, flowing the text into multiple areas can easily make our content almost completely unreadable.

links.title: Creating Non-Rectangular Layouts With CSS Shapes
links.description: Today we can create all kinds of shapes with CSS using CSS transforms, but all these shapes do not affect the flow of the content inside or around them. That is, if you create a triangle or a trapezoid with CSS, for example, the shape created does not define or affect the way the text inside it flows, or the way inline text around it does.

links.title: CSS Shapes 101
links.description: The new CSS Shapes specification is changing that. Introduced by Adobe in mid-2012, its goal is to provide web designers with a new way to change how the content flows inside and around arbitrarily complex shapes‚Äîsomething we‚Äôve never been able to do before, not even with JavaScript.

links.title: Demo for Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, by Lewis Carroll
links.description: Using CSS Shapes to enhance visual storytelling.

links.title: Good-Looking Shapes Gallery
links.description: Development of CSS Shapes has been underway for about two years, and we‚Äôve been regularly heralding its progress here. Many of those reports have focused on the evolution of the spec and implementations, and they‚Äôve included examples that emphasized basics over beauty. This article is an attempt to tilt the balance back towards good-looking. Listed below are simple shapes demos that we think look pretty good. Everyone on Adobe‚Äôs CSS Shapes engineering team contributed at least one.

links.title: Demo for Alice in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll
CSS Shapes Gallery
links.description: There‚Äôs a live CodePen.io version of each demo in the gallery. Click on the demo screenshot or one of the handy links to take a look. You‚Äôll want to view the demos with a browser that supports Shapes and you‚Äôll need to enable CSS Shapes in that browser.

title: Code and Typography
sum: Outsiders of type world may not believe how much coding is involved in every aspect of Type Design and Web Typography. Code and Math are embedded in Type Design's nature. I am always fascinated by innovation in Type and Typography through programming. I collect a list of open source coding projects surrounding the topic of Type and mostly Web Typography. There are more to be done, and there are a few ideas in my head that I need to get out. Typography sits in an exciting intersection of art, technology and craftsmanship.

links.title: opentype.js
links.description: opentype.js is an OpenType and TrueType font parser and writer. It allows you to access the letterforms of text from the browser or node.js.

links.title: FreeType
links.description: FreeType is a freely available software library to render fonts. It is written in C, designed to be small, efficient, highly customizable, and portable while capable of producing high quality output (glyph images) of most vector and bitmap font formats. Some products that use FreeType for rendering fonts on screen or on paper, either exclusively or partially: GNU/Linux, iOS, Android, ChromeOS, ReactOS, Ghostscript.

links.title: Kern.js
links.description: Make web kerning suck less.

links.title: JavaScript/CSS Font Detector
links.description: JavaScript code to detect available availability of a particular font in a browser using JavaScript and CSS.

links.title: textillate.js
links.description: Textillate.js combines some awesome libraries to provide a ease-to-use plugin for applying CSS3 animations to any text.

links.title: Font‚ÄëTo‚ÄëWidth
links.description: Font‚ÄëTo‚ÄëWidth (FTW!) is a script by Nick Sherman and Chris Lewis that takes advantage of large type families to fit pieces of text snugly within their containers. Unlike other text-fitting tools like FitText.js, Font‚ÄëTo‚ÄëWidth does not scale the font-size (at least not by default). Instead, it chooses a width or weight variant according to what fits best, and then allows for letter- and word-spacing adjustments as needed.

links.title: FitText.js
links.description: FitText makes font-sizes flexible. Use this plugin on your fluid or responsive layout to achieve scalable headlines that fill the width of a parent element.

links.title: Blast.js
links.description: Blast.js separates text in order to facilitate typographic manipulation. It has four delimiters built in: character, word, sentence, and element. Alternatively, Blast can match custom regular expressions and phrases.

links.title: Font.js
links.description: This library adds a Font object to the collection of predefined objects available to you when doing JS coding for the web. You are probably already familiar with new Image() for loading images through the browser; this object does something similar for fonts. Font.js can be used for both remote fonts (from URL) or system fonts (by font family name), which allows you to use the Font object as a way to detect whether a specific system font is installed at the client, for implementing typesetting fallbacks and failsafes.

links.title: Squishy
links.description: Squishy is a jQuery plugin that automatically resizes text to exactly fit the container with no extra work on your part.

links.title: SlabText
links.description: Put simply, the script splits headlines into rows before resizing each row to fill the available horizontal space. The ideal number of characters to set on each row is calculated by dividing the available width by the pixel font-size ‚Äì the script then uses this ideal character count to split the headline into word combinations that are displayed as separate rows of text.

links.title: HatchShow
links.description: HatchShow is a jQuery typesetting plugin. It balances measures.

links.title: FunnyText.js
links.description: Create funny and crazy moving texts in a simple way.

links.title: Simple Text Rotator
links.description: Add a super simple rotating text to your website with little to no markup.

links.title: jumble
links.description: A jQuery plugin that jumbles up the colours of your text headers, and can also animate them. Choose a colour range for the colours to be jumbled amongst, and set params for whether the shuffle is based on brightness or satuation hue.

links.title: CircleType.js
links.description: CircleType.js is a tiny (2kb) jQuery plugin that lets you curve type on the web.

links.title: jQuery Bacon
links.description: Allows you to align text to a bezier curve or a line.

links.title: Designing Obsidian with Andy Clymer
links.description: Designers of type and lettering make use of custom tools to draw and manufacture their product, this is as true today as it was in the time of punchcutting and steelplate engraving. After the design of the Surveyor family of typefaces came to a close, an exploration was made into finding an approach where custom tools could be used to help prototype the kinds of highly intricate designs that may have been too complex to otherwise consider putting into development. This process led to the design of Obsidian, a typeface that is elaborately shaded in a style that makes reference to the same nineteenth century tradition of engraved lettering as Surveyor is rooted in. Andy Clymer, a senior designer at Hoefler & Co. and instructor in the Type@Cooper program, will share a look at the design process, the custom tools involved, and some of the unexpected challenges and discoveries found while designing Obsidian.

title: Generative Art
sum: Processing is great, but personally, I don't see why javascript couldn't take over the prime place of processing in generative art or even creative coding in general. Javascript is more open, more shareable, its community is more welcoming and diverse. I am designing a course to teach how to do Generative Art with javascript.

links.title: Generative Design
links.description: The book Generative Design describes the creation of images by using codes. An image is not created manually, but instead by translating a visual idea into a set of rules and then implementing it in a programming language. Such a program can not only create a single image but also design complete visual worlds when parameters are changed.

links.title: Programming Graphics I: Introduction to Generative Art
links.description: Generative art is all about using programming to generate artwork that is algorithmically defined and created. In this project-based class, you'll learn how to create your own series of patterns using generative art techniques and computer programming!

links.title: Doodling in Math and more

The book includes high-quality examples of generative art, along with the specific programmatic steps author and artist Matt Pearson followed to create each unique piece using the Processing programming language.

The Nature of Code

How can understanding the mathematical principles behind our physical world help us to create digital worlds? This book focuses on the programming strategies and techniques behind computer simulations of natural systems using Processing.

links.title: Vi Hart
links.description: I am Vi Hart! I am a real person, and I make videos and virtual reality and other things. Sorry about the bright yellow. It amuses me. This is my personal website, not some ‚ÄúVi Hart brand Websperience‚Äù created for your enjoyment or education or whatever.

links.description: Hi. I‚Äôm Jason, and this website is a collection of some of my favorite interactive projects. I have over 15 years experience designing and building playful interactive things. links.description: My name is Anders Hoff. I write algorithms that generate images. To me it is fascinating how complex and intricate results you can get from a set of simple rules. My works are often a result of me trying to recreate some behaviour I have seen elsewhere. Either in nature, in previous works by others or in mathematical concepts.

links.title: Michelle Chandra's processing work
links.description: Michelle Chandra is a designer, front end developer, and artist interested in the creative and artistic application of data to varied mediums including maps, photography and music. She studied art, tech and code at NYU‚Äôs Interactive Telecommunications Program. Her work has been featured in many publications including the Daily Mail, theWashington Post, Engadget, Gizmodo, and the Creator‚Äôs Project. title: Everything Color
sum: Starting today, I am going to focus my research on topics that I am going to teach this summer at OfCourse in China. The class is focused on typography, color, and motion, explored through Javascript creative coding. I want to research color a bit deeper than last time, particularly in regard to the coding aspect of it. And oh boy did I find treasure ‚òû ‚ÄúRGB/XYZ Matrices‚Äù. Last time was when reading the technical documentation on CSS Matrix, and today is the other occasion. Kids, stay in school!

links.title: Exploring Color Theory with Blender
links.description: Blender is an open source 3D modeling/rendering application. Because you have to tell it explicitly what to do at every step, working with color geometry in Blender is a really good way to sharpen your understanding of the technical details. links.title: Ultimate Guide to Color Theory for Designers
links.description: This guide explores the subject of color relative to web and graphic design. links.title: Blending Modes in CSS: Color Theory and Practical Application
links.description: You might be familiar with ‚Äúblending modes‚Äù if you‚Äôre a Photoshop user; they allow you to combine layers in different ways and they‚Äôre great fun to play with. Blending modes in CSS, however, aren‚Äôt supported universally, but they are certainly on their way.

links.title: Do Brand Colors Translate to Instagram?

links.description: Here‚Äôs a 16 lessons I‚Äôve learned while stabilizing a primary palette, tint and shade choices, secondary palettes, and solving for accessible contrast.

links.description: Using the chromaticities and reference whites of common RGB working spaces, I have done the math for you to compute the RGB-to-XYZ and XYZ-to-RGB matrices. Note that these matrices are given relative to their own reference whites. If you examine the matrices for these working spaces found inside ICC profiles (through the redColorantTag, greenColorantTag and blueColorantTag), those matrices will always be relative to D50, and therefore, the colorants have been subjected to a chromatic adaptation transformation if the working space reference white is not also D50.

links.title: Using python and k-means to find the dominant colors in images
links.description: This approach uses k-means clustering to cluster the pixels in groups based on their color. The center of those resulting clusters are then the "dominant" colors. k-means is a great fit for this problem because it is (usually) fast. links.title: Colour Contrast Check
links.description: The Colour Contrast Check Tool allows to specify a foreground and a background colour and determine if they provide enough of a contrast "when viewed by someone having color deficits or when viewed on a black and white screen"[W3C]. The tool will indicate that the colours pass the test if both the colour difference and the brightness difference exceed their threshold. It will indicate that it sort of passes if only one of the two values exceed their threshold. And finally, it'll fail to pass if neither value exceeds its threshold.

links.title: Techniques For Accessibility Evaluation And Repair Tools
links.description: This document describes techniques that Web accessibility validation tools may use to evaluate the conformance of HTML documents to the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 (WCAG 1.0). links.description: The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for the following: Large Text: Large-scale text and images of large-scale text have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1; Incidental: Text or images of text that are part of an inactive user interface component, that are pure decoration, that are not visible to anyone, or that are part of a picture that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast requirement. title: Opinions on Rebrand
sum: Yesterday the beloved Instagram revealed its new icon. The rebrand has evoked a lot of critique and discussion, which intrigued me to find out the mentality behind people's opinion on rebrands. Is it the fear of change, or the phenomenon of "everyone is a designer", or there is truly articulated design reasons to hate a seemingly fine rebrand? The digital world is noisy, the comments are flooding the Twittersphere. I often find myself in a storm of opinions and could not decide who I stand behind, or rather, where I hide. This research is a documentation of my struggle to navigate the rebrand critique world, and trying to make sense and grow as a graphic designer.

links.title: New Icon for Instagram done In-house #Gradient #Minimal #Life #CatsOfInstagram
links.description: The skeuomorphic camera icon that has accompanied Instagram until today is a modern-day classic. Not because it‚Äôs good ‚Äî it‚Äôs not, really ‚Äî but because of its omnipresence in users‚Äô phone screens. I bet it‚Äôs on the home screen of 99% of people who have the app and who tap it very regularly. When the iPhone first came out ‚Äî if you‚Äôll remember ‚Äî skeuomorphism was the default aesthetic and now, for better or worse, it‚Äôs all about flat design with a dash of optional gradients so it‚Äôs no surprise that‚Äôs where Instagram has headed. If there was any surprise it‚Äôs that Instagram held on to the skeuomorphism for a relatively long five years.

links.title: New Logo and Identity for The Met by Wolff Olins, Making the Mummies Dense
links.description: But the museum felt that this geometrically-constructed M was too reliant on symbolism. So instead, they wrote out the name as ‚Äúan original drawing, a hybrid that combines and connects serif and sans serif, classical and modern letterforms. In this respect, it reflects the scope of the Museum‚Äôs collection and the connections that exist within it‚Äù. In other words the letters touch each other.

links.title: You Could Almost Do Anything Pt. I
links.description: One of the central aims of the modern minimalist project is to remove as much visually representational information as possible, despite the inherent contradictions that implies for the design practitioner. Abstraction is one of the primary tools modern minimalist designers needlessly corrupt in order to prevent meaning from being made of what otherwise might be communicative visual signs. This preference for intentional obscurantism brings status to a class of would-be elite designers and their sycophants.

links.title: A New Look for Instagram
links.description: Today we‚Äôre introducing a new look. You‚Äôll see an updated icon and app design for Instagram. Inspired by the previous app icon, the new one represents a simpler camera and the rainbow lives on in gradient form.

links.title: Tobias van Schneider's thoughts on Instagram's new design and logo
links.description: Tobias van Schneider: After many people asked me on Twitter about my thoughts on the new icon and Instagram design refinements, I thought it might be best to make a quick video. PS: I do not work at Instagram, I'm just someone who loves the app.

links.title: The Metropolitan Museum of Art‚Äôs New Logo Is a Typographic Bus Crash
links.description: As the Metropolitan Museum of Art busts out of its Beaux-Arts shell and opens its Madison Avenue outpost in the old Whitney, the institution is trying on a fresh identity, or at least enshrining an old nickname in a new look. In its logo, the Met is now THE MET, the two short words printed in scarlet letters, stacked and squashed together. The whole ensemble looks like a red double-decker bus that has stopped short, shoving the passengers into each other‚Äôs backs. Worse, the entire top half of the new logo consists of the word the.

links.quote: Whether we want to acknowledge it or not, anyone evaluating a brand new logo at first glance is ‚Äî to paraphrase my partner Paula Scher ‚Äî reviewing a three-act play based on what they see the moment the curtain goes up. Or, to put it differently, they think they're judging a diving competition when in fact they're judging a swimming competition. The question isn't what kind of splash you make. It's how long you can keep your head above water.

links.title: Fall of the Designer Part I: Fashionable Nonsense

links.title: The Met Explains Its Controversial New Logo

Lee says one goal of the rebranding is to ‚Äúmake the experience much more accessible to people,‚Äù and Lisa Smith, the creative director at Wolff Olins, says the font, the palette, and the photography styles are ‚Äúmuch more simple and friendly and global.‚Äù The Met‚Äôs lead designer and its head of marketing offer similar rhetoric. title: Font Subsetting
sum: In Dec. 2014, on a vacation trip to New Orleans, I came up with the idea of font subsetting, to address the web font issue for CJK fonts. I was so excited that I drafted an email immediately in the hotel to a type friend I met online (GitHub), who has experience building font serving open source project and also has an Asian background. But of course, this idea was not new, as "Nothing is new under the sun". I found out about justfont, which did exactly what I envisioned. A few months later I started to talk to Typekit about joining the team, and it turned out Typekit has the dynamic subsetting technology as well, ready to be launched in Japan. The technology is there, the real question now is why it is not as ground shattering as I imagined? Why is Chinese web design still not pushing as hard on typography as the West? Maybe it is the intrinsic beauty in the language character itself that shadowed the power of good typeface? Or eastern design has not evolved to the stage to be caring about such detail? I am leaning towards the former.

links.title: justfont
links.description: Even though various webfont services are available for English texts, such as google webfonts, creating a Chinese webfont service is an enormous challenge, considering the file sizes of Chinese fonts are quite large. But we have exceeded all imaginations to create a Chinese webfont service which boasts the same service speed as English webfonts. Besides utilizing dynamic sub-setting which effectively shrinks Chinese fonts, we pursue paramount perfection in every presented detail, offering you incredible instantaneous display.

links.title: Announcing East Asian web font support and new font browsing tools for Japanese customers
links.description: East Asian fonts are big. Really, REALLY big. Last year we announced the introduction of Source Han Sans, with glyph counts ranging from just under 18,000 for Japanese and nearly 31,000 for Simplified Chinese. Not only do they have a lot of glyphs, they have a lot of megabytes to go with them ‚Äì from 4.2 to 8.8MB per font! How are you going to use those on your site?! Well, here‚Äôs what we have done: when you add an East Asian font family to your kit, it will automatically become what we call a dynamic kit. In a dynamic kit, you‚Äôll have a new Character Set option in the kit editor called Dynamic Subsetting. When your dynamic kit JavaScript loads in the browser, it will detect your page‚Äôs character usage and request a dynamic subset for the glyphs needed for each member of the family. This makes for very small fonts, with incredibly fast load times.

links.title: Slash Page Load Times With CSS Font Subsetting
links.description: The wide availability of web fonts has enabled sites to become typographical wonderlands, at the cost of increased page size and longer load times. Performance-focused developers already optimize their images and CSS; it makes sense that we should also optimize web fonts. The good news is that doing is fairly easy: by creating your own custom font or supplying your web font hosting service with a simple variable value, you can load only the glyphs that you need for the text you have on the page, rather than the entire range of characters, numbers and symbols in the font, reducing page load times.

While Fonts.com Web Fonts has used dynamic subsetting for all of our East Asian fonts since its inception in 2010, we‚Äôd like to explore implementing the technology for other languages and use cases including mobile targeted content, dynamic branded content, social apps or rich media ads.

title: Font Loading
sum: FOUT or FOIT or something else? Behind these nerdy code-like acronyms, it is how much some of us care about web typography: the milliseconds delay matters. From a joke on the presidential candidates' websites to serious long draft to the w3 standard on native font loading API, Font Loading is an interesting and important area in Web Typography to dig in. It shows the difference between Web Typography and Print Typography: print doesn't need loading time to render the text, it is all pre-loaded and pre-rendered. But as "The New Web Typography" points out, the web is a new medium, it brings new challenges to typography, and that is what makes now the most exciting time to get in.

links.title: Loading Web Fonts with the Web Font Loader
links.description: In fact, this practice of letting a browser hide all the text that should be styled with a custom font is now called the ‚ÄòFlash of Invisible Text‚Äô, or FOIT, and is often regarded as the worst of all possible options. Scott Jehl has argued that this is a pretty bad idea for both performance and usability. Likewise, the Typekit help page on the matter states that ‚Äúthe FOUT approach makes for more immediately usable pages, particularly on slower network connections.‚Äù So as designers and developers we have to make a decision between FOUT or FOIT.

links.title: Critical Web Fonts

This method builds on the Flash of Faux Text (FOFT) using a two stages loading process (sounds like, but is not actually rocket science), but instead of a full Roman web font in the first stage, it loads a small subset of the Roman web font, in this case with only the upper case and lower case alphabetic characters.

links.description: After we‚Äôve defeated the Flash of Invisible Text, we also want to decrease the amount of reflow a user sees when the font switches from fallback to @font-face. We already split our CSS into critical and deferred, why not fonts? Prioritize your fonts by loading only your roman (or plain/normal) font first, which will cause the browser to use font synthesis to create faux-bold/italic versions automatically. Next, trigger requests for the real bold and italic fonts. This will minimize the amount of reflow while the user is reading the content.

links.title: How we use web fonts responsibly, or, avoiding a @font-face-palm
links.description: Using @font-face to load custom web fonts is a great feature to give our sites a unique and memorable aesthetic. However, when you use custom fonts on the web using standard techniques, they can slow down page load speed and hamper performance‚Äîboth real and perceived. Luckily, we've figured out some methods to apply them carefully to ensure your site correctly balances usability, performance and style.

links.title: loadCSS

This is desirable in many cases, but when loading stylesheets that are not critical to the initial rendering of a page, loadCSS (and upcoming web standards mentioned below) allows you to load stylesheets asynchronously, so they don‚Äôt block page rendering.

Here we‚Äôll go through exactly what to do, how to do it and why it‚Äôs important to address getting your fallback embedding and styles sorted out and just a bit more complete.

title: Combining Typefaces
sum: In ‚ÄúThe Three Phases to Improve Your Typography‚Äù, I described Classic Phase and Master Phase. In retrospect, I could have made it much more clear and simpler by saying, Classic Phase is when you stick to typographic rules and master phase is when you know when and how to break them. Maybe ‚Äúrule‚Äù is a poor choice of word, ‚Äúprinciple‚Äù is a better word. The author of ‚ÄúThe Value of Multi-Typeface Design Design‚Äù really amazed me with her knowledge and eyes for detail in typography. A must read.

links.title: The Value of Multi-Typeface Design
links.description: I want to present a counter argument and speak to the value of eclectic type systems, and how you can structure your projects in ways that will allow you to use more typefaces together effectively.

links.title: Combining Typefaces: Free guide to great typography
links.description: This very brief ‚Äúpocket guide‚Äù is for designers and developers who want to make better choices about type and build their typographic expertise. Successful typeface combinations are partly a matter of good taste, which can be tough to develop. And finding typefaces that work well together often takes more time than we (or our managers, or our spouses!) think it should.

links.title: Eight Tips for Combining Typefaces
links.description: The more effective combinations usually rely on typographic principles. These principles are not scientific, rigid, or fail-safe; all of them can be broken, but they should all be understood.

links.title: Best Practices of Combining Typefaces
links.description: Creating great typeface combinations is an art, not a science. Indeed, the beauty of typography has no borders. While there are no absolute rules to follow, it is crucial that you understand and apply some best practices when combining fonts in a design. When used with diligence and attention, these principles will always yield suitable results. Today we will take a close look at some the best practices for combining typefaces ‚Äî as well as some blunders to avoid.

Just peruse this list of ideas and see what strikes you as interesting, and then pursue creating your own interesting typeface pairs!

links.description: The BBOFC is an expansive collection of carefully crafted typeface pair samples. The font pairings in BBOFC will inspire you and give you back time you need for your design projects. Use the combination examples straight out of the BBOFC in your next project, with other typeface software, or use them as a springboard for your own creativity. title: OpenType Features
sum: The highlight of my last year was working with Tim Brown on launching the "Caring about OpenType features" lesson on practice Typekit. Doing the lesson helped me understand what OpenType is and means to Web Typography. But a few days ago, while making this website you are looking at, I discovered a new OpenType feature I wasn't aware of, historical ligature. OpenType is a treasure land, and I certainly enjoyed digging in.

links.title: Caring about OpenType features
links.description: More than fancy swashes and superfluous ligatures, OpenType features are font superpowers. The best, most capable typefaces are full of sophisticated reasoning and delightful surprises ‚Äî things that are often integral to the design of the type itself, or that help it work better for specific typesetting tasks. Using OpenType features is easy when you know they exist, are enabled, and are supported in browsers and applications.

links.title: Advanced web typography: A recap on OpenType features
links.description: Browser support has improved, progress seems to have slowed and the varying levels of support are still pretty confusing. So let‚Äôs try and demystify some of this. The four areas I covered previously were: ligatures, small caps and old style numerals (with subsets for polyfilling), swashes (with subsets again), and stylesets.

links.title: Introducing Normalize-OpenType.css
links.description: Following the same normalising approach as its namesake, Normalize-OpenType.css only includes CSS that applies OpenType features to basic HTML elements, like <body>, <table>, and <time>. If your font includes OpenType features, your typography will be improved in supported browsers. If not, nothing else will be affected.

links.title: The OpenType Cookbook
links.description: OpenType features allow fonts to behave smartly. This behavior can do simple things (e.g. change letters to small caps) or they can do complex things (e.g. insert swashes, alternates, and ligatures to make text set in a script font feel handmade). This cookbook aims to be a designer‚Ä¶

links.title: Tomorrow‚Äôs Web Type Today Series

OpenType features should be as easy to apply as bold and italics. 2. OpenType features should cascade predictably. 3. OpenType features should fallback gracefully.

It allows users to interpolate many intermediate "instances" of the typeface. The fonts have one or more "axes" which might typically represent the weight, width, or optical size of the font. Thus the user can generate a very large number of variations from a single font - thus providing unprecedented flexibility.

links.title: Font Hinting and the Future of Responsive Typography

In other words, hinting is to fonts what responsive layout is to websites. It allows a single font file to adapt to a variety of contexts, the same way CSS allows a single HTML file to adapt to a variety of contexts.

title: Vertical Rhythm
sum: While designing this website, I was torn on whether I should make it stick to a vertical grid. I read many articles about this particular topic. The one I agree the most is ‚ÄúThe New Web Typography‚Äù. For the past few years, Web Typography is playing catch up, trying to achieve what has been done on the print. Web is a new medium, very different than print, and it is facing a lot of new challenges. Instead of doing everything ‚Äúby the book‚Äù, new rules should be defined, and old rules that don't apply anymore should be tossed. Treat Web Typography as its own unique art form and medium.

I realized that the biggest argument Tom was making in the article was that web typography is broken because type doesn‚Äôt sit perfectly on a baseline grid‚Ä¶ I knew the importance of Vertical Rhythm and the baseline grid. I also knew that details matter when it comes to design. But is this one detail enough to break web typography?

We‚Äôll learn about: How to choose a font face; How to choose a font size; Using a grid; Working out the measure; Vertical rhythm and baseline grids; Choosing a typographic scale; How to use proper quotes; How to use proper dashes; How to use proper ellipses; How to hang punctuation; Dealing with images in grids.

links.description: Vertical rhythm is about spacing body text or, more generally, vertical stacked elements, in a consistent manner to give structure and hierarchy to your content. The baseline on the other hand implies that content spread in multiple columns is horizontally aligned. These two key principles will always ensure your content with structure, hierarchy, and consistency, and make your body text more readable.

links.title: Designing Faster with a Baseline Grid
links.description: However, grids are nothing new and can be traced back to Middle Ages: in the 1220s/1240s, French architect Villard de Honnecourt designed construction canons based on geometry. These principles were later studied by typographers and designers in the beginning of the 20th century to reverse-engineer medieval canons of page construction. Among them, Van de Graaf, Rosarivo, and ultimately Tschichold who popularized his predecessors‚Äô discoveries in his book The Form of the Book: Essays on the Morality of Good Design.

links.title: Why is Vertical Rhythm an Important Typography Practice?
links.description: So, in summary, Vertical Rhythm is important because it follows one of the principles of design ‚Äì repetition. Repetition has the ability to make things feel that they belong together. It gives the feeling that someone has thought it all out, like it‚Äôs part of the plan. After discovering the link between Vertical Rhythm and Repetition, we went on and figured out several ways we could replicate 24px to bring some variations to the design. Finally, after getting tired of repeating 24px vertically, we tried repeating 24px horizontally as well.

Stanford professor Donald Knuth begins with his article, ‚ÄúThe Concept of a Meta-font‚Äù (Winter 1981). links.title: The letter S
links.description: Several years ago when I began to look at the problem of designing suitable alphabets for use with modern printing equipment, I found that 25 of the letters were comparatively easy to deal with. The other letter was 'S'. For three days and nights I had a terrible time trying to understand how a proper 'S' could really be defined. The solution I finally came up with turned out to involve some interesting mathematics, and I believe that students of calculus and analytic geometry may enjoy looking into the question as I did. The purpose of this paper is to explain what I now consider to be the 'right' mathematics underlying printed S's, and also to give an example of the METAFONT language I have recently been developing.

It was created by Donald Knuth with his Metafont program, and was most recently updated in 1992. Computer Modern, or variants of it, remains very widely used in scientific publishing, especially in disciplines that make frequent use of mathematical notation.

The construction of a typeface is an art form and this manual is written for people who wish to advance the quality of mathematical typesetting. The METAFONTbook enables readers, with only minimal computer science or word processing experience, to master the basic as well as the more advanced features of METAFONT programming. With this manual, readers will learn how to write a program using METAFONT that can customize a type design that already exists, create an entire alphabet from scratch, and create logos or special symbols.

links.description: In this collection, the second in the series, Knuth explores the relationship between computers and typography. The present volume, in the words of the author, is a legacy to all the work he has done on typography. When he thought he would take a few years' leave from his main work on the art of computer programming, as is well known, the short typographic detour lasted more than a decade. When type designers, punch cutters, typographers, book historians, and scholars visited the University during this period, it gave to Stanford what some consider to be its golden age of digital typography. By the author's own admission, the present work is one of the most difficult books that he has prepared. This is truly a work that only Knuth himself could have produced.
